awd_abstract_narration:
One of the most basic questions about the protein molecules in the living cell is the manner by which they interact with one another. How proteins recognize and bind (stick) to the correct partner(s) is one of the ways information is communicated within and between the cells. This is how cells process information and make decisions at the molecular level. Atomic-level information is essential to explain the specific interactions between proteins in terms of structure and dynamics. The research project consists in developing and improving the computer-based approach of "molecular dynamics" to calculate and predict accurately how proteins bind to one another. Molecular dynamics (MD) consists of using Newton's classical equation, force = mass x acceleration, to simulate the motions of all the atoms as a function of time. The MD simulation, although an approximation to the real world, provides detailed information about the time course of the atomic motions that cannot be accessed experimentally. The approach based on atomic models and MD simulations is advantageous because it does not rely on any particular assumption about protein binding. Being able to predict the possible binding partners of a protein from computations will open the door to a much better understanding of living cells. In addition to developing methods that will be of broad utility to the scientific community, the project will provide inter-disciplinary training and mentoring to young scientists at the undergraduate and graduate level (including members of under-represented minorities), as well as outreach to high school students. 

The research project consists in improving the theoretical and computational methods to calculate and predict accurately how molecules bind to one another. According to the theory of statistical thermodynamics, the quantity that controls the association of molecules is the binding free energy. This mathematically well-defined quantity can be calculated using computer simulations of atomic models of the molecules of interest. Molecular dynamics (MD) simulation can help elucidate the fundamental principles governing the binding of biological molecules at the atomic level. MD consists of constructing detailed atomic models of the macromolecules and using Newton's classical equation, F=MA, to literally simulate the dynamical motions of all the atoms as a function of time. The microscopic forces (the "F" in Newton's equation) are approximated by using a potential function, also called a force field, constructed from simple analytical functions. Validating the accuracy of the force field is also an important use of computations based on MD simulations. The calculated trajectory, though an approximation to the real world, provides detailed information about the time course of the atomic motions, which is impossible to access experimentally. Efforts in this area are likely to have a large impact because biology is entering a quantitative era that requires an ability to predict the binding of molecules. The first specific objective of the research is the design and development of novel computational methodologies addressing the specific challenges presented by protein-protein interactions. Sampling the large number of accessible configurations of the solvated proteins is critical. Simply running longer unbiased MD is not going to lead to success, and special enhanced sampling methods are needed to achieve this. The second objective is to validate and test the computational methodology and assess the accuracy of the atomic force field on the basis of well-known protein-protein complexes. It is important to know if the results are correct for the binding free energy, the entropy and enthalpy decomposition, and the kinetic rate of association. In the last stage, the objectives are focused on testing the computational method with respect to increasingly challenging situations.

This project is jointly funded by the Molecular Biophysics Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences in the Directorate for Biological Sciences and the Chemical Theory, Models, and Computational Methods Program in the Division of Chemistry in the Directorate of Mathematical and Physical Sciences.

Accomplishments* What are the major goals of the project?


The overarching goal of this proposal is to gain mechanistic understanding of protein-protein association and recognition processes by establishing a robust molecular dynamics (MD) computational strategy based on a rigorous statistical mechanical framework. From this point of view, we must first design and implement novel formational sampling schemes, and advance on the thermodynamic characterization of the Barstar-Barnase. Furthermore, we have made a lot of progress with novel sampling methods based on hybrid algorithms combining nonequilibrium molecular dynamics and Monte Carlo (neMD/MC). Those offer a powerful avenue for improving the sampling efficiency of computer simulations of complex systems. These neMD/MC algorithms are also increasingly finding use in applications where conventional approaches are impractical.


* What was accomplished under these goals (you must provide information for at least one of the 4 categories below)?

 
Major Activities:

 
1) Donghyuk Suh has now graduated (PhD in Chemistry, June 2019). During the year he has contributed to testing free energy methodologies, leading to one publication and also a large calculation of the binding free energy of four barstar/barnase complexes (wild-type and the three mutants D39A, R87A, D39A/R87A), leading to a second publication.


2) Nabil Faruk (graduate student) has made progress with the Contrastive Divergence parameter training methodology to refined the coarse-grained potential of the UpSide program to predict protein-protein complexes. His training set includes more than 300 complexes, each comprising one native pose and about 100 decoys. A manuscript is in preparation that will soon be submitted. He is expected to graduate around June 2021.


3) Ziwei He (graduate student) has completed the analyis of simulations of barstar-barnase complexation based on a coarse-grained model to compare the accuracy of straight Markov State Model (MSM) approach together with the discrete transition-based reweighting analysis method (TRAM) and biased umbrella sampling simulations. This was published Ziwei He1,   Fabian Paul, and   Benoît Roux. "A critical perspective on Markov state model treatments of protein–protein association using coarse-grained simulations". J. Chem. Phys. 154, 084101 (2021); https://doi.org/10.1063/5.0039144. She is now finishing the analysis of the all-atom simulations using the same methodology. A manuscript describing these results is in preparation. She is expected to graduate around July 2021.

4) Chris Boughter (graduate student in joint mentorship with Dr. Erin Adams) has now graduated (PhD in Biophysics, January 2021). 
has been characterizing the protein-protein complex that is involved in an immune response, which begins with sensing pyrophosphate-containing molecules called phosphoantigens (pAgs) that are present in infected cells or accumulate intracellularly in certain tumor cells via the intracellular domain of the butyrophilin 3A1 (BTN3A1) molecule. He is pursuing these calculation with a Blue Waters allocation.


5) Prithviraj Nandigrami (postdoc) has now left the lab. We are finishing a manuscript that should be submitted soon on the studies of the binding specificity of extracellular domains of cell surface receptors and ligands that mediate cell-cell communication, adhesion, and initiation of signaling events. Dpr (named after Deffective in Proboscis Extension Response) proteins belong to immunoglobulin superfamily. 

Specific Objectives:


Design, implement and test novel sampling schemes combining Metropolis Monte Carlo (MC) with proposed moves generated by non-equilibrium MD.Apply Markov State Model framework to protein-protein complexes.Expand the string method to determine an optimal separation pathway for of two proteins in complex.Refine the coarse-grained potential of UpSide to predict the correct docking pose of proteins.
Significant Results:
Our most significant result in the last year has been the completion of the String method for Protein-Protein Binding Free Energy Calculation [Suh, D; Jo, S.; Jiang, W.; Chipot, C.; Roux, B.  String method for Protein-Protein Binding Free Energy Calculation.  Journal of Chemical Theory and Computation (in press)].

Key outcomes or Other achievements:


We continue to make excellent progress on the design design and implementation of novel sampling schemes combining Metropolis Monte Carlo (MC) with proposed moves generated by non-equilibrium MD, and also on the implementation of a rigorous strategy based on the String Method to treat the protein-protein association/dissociation process and re-formulate standard binding free energy within this strategy. 


* What opportunities for training and professional development has the project provided?


The research has provided a great opportunity to train 4 graduate students (Donghyuk Suh, Nabil Faruk, Ziwei He, Chris Boughter) and one current postdoc (Jonathan Thirman who is now supported by a fellowship from the DOE).  Donghyuk Suh has just defended his PhD thesis (Chemistry, Univ Chicago) and graduated in June 2019 and Chris Boughter defended his PhD thesis (Biophsyics, Univ Chicago) and graduate in January 2021. In the fall 2018, Ziwei He has visited the lab of Dr Frank Noe (Berlin University) to establish a collaborative effort on protein-protein binding specificity.
